history.content:
Transfer student here too. I did 170 and 126 together in one semester and I felt like the workload were super heavy. The concepts for both classes are challenging and need time to digest and contemplate if you really want to learn them well; they both have weekly homework, which are 5-6 questions long, each question would potentially take hours to finish. They both have a final project, will take 2-3 weeks' commitment to finish 126 has 6-7 labs.  2 mids and a final, tests are challenging.

 

So I highly recommend not adding 100 on top of those two classes... From what I heard, 100 are currently adding new materials and more workload, and they make the tests harder than before. 

 

If you are aiming for industry, maybe you can do 170 + 100 instead of 170 + 126. 100 is really practical and helpful for finding DA oriented job in the industry, at least several of my friends major in ECS and Stats agree on this.


______________

I'm going to offer conflicting advice here. If you felt like you kept up well in those classes you mentioned, I think you should go for 126 + 170 + 100 (or another technical class). It will give you a great skill set for data science and a deep understanding for the topics you'll be dealing with. Yes, 100 might be great for giving you practical insights into the work you might be doing, but only the deep technical knowledge you'll gain in 126 will allow you to do data science as opposed to some data analytics work.


In general, I'd keep up your confidence - if you work hard, you'll be able to take that course load without any problems, which will also give you an edge once looking for internships.

Transfer student here too. I did 170 and 126 together in one semester and I felt like the workload were super heavy. The concepts for both classes are challenging and need time to digest and contemplate if you really want to learn them well; they both have weekly homework, which are 5-6 questions long, each question would potentially take hours to finish. They both have a final project, will take 2-3 weeks' commitment to finish 126 has 6-7 labs.  2 mids and a final, tests are challenging.

So I highly recommend not adding 100 on top of those two classes... From what I heard, 100 are currently adding new materials and more workload, and they make the tests harder than before. 

If you are aiming for industry, maybe you can do 170 + 100 instead of 170 + 126. 100 is really practical and helpful for finding DA oriented job in the industry, at least several of my friends major in ECS and Stats agree on this.

children.subject:
Looks good already! You could add Math 110 for Spring 2020. It's not that heavy, and if you PNP the HSS, then that will be a very doable schedule. It'll give you a deep understanding of linear algebra, which will help you with many ML related concepts.

Assuming you'll be recruiting full-time in Fall 2020, your courses won't matter as much anyhow. If you get a good internship in summer 2020 and get a return offer, you might not be recruiting at all! Then it's really up to you what interests you and what you feel will help you the most based on the experience you'll have at that point. I feel like graduate classes in AI/ML, Stats or Math might be interesting - or take something like Logic, Business or Econ, which might be very helpful down the line, when you're speaking with the business people in your company. Besides, it's also great to spend some time learning something you won't get the chance to focus on once your actually working!

As another tip, you might just want to look at some job postings for companies/positions that appeal to you. They'll tell you pretty upfront about the skills/experiences they look for - then just take the classes whose descriptions match with the skills you still have to develop. Besides, it'll tell you what projects you could pursue in your own time to make you an even more competitive candidate (despite Kaggle ;))

Thank you so much! The only reason I’m trying to fit in data100 is because I feel companies will want people who have taken that since it seems it teaches all the soft skills for data science. Would taking it in the Fall help me for internship recruiting in the summer ?

I’m almost in the same boat, taking EE126 (Rama), 61B (Hilfinger) and Data 100 (Hug).  Adding 61C (Garcia) for Phase 2 and trying to figure out if it’s reasonable to leave this schedule, or switch out 100 with 188 if the schedule is too many projects, but potentially not be as ready for SWE internships for interviews for next summer.  Please give feedback...

@First Anon: Well you could take Math 110 instead of Data 100, which would probably give you a better foundation, and then spend the rest of your summer doing Data science projects to gain all the "soft skills" that Data 100 would teach you. I think either would work, depends on your motivation regarding personal projects.
@Second Anon: Neither 188+100 or 61C will help that much with SWE interviews. 61B and 170 are regarded as the most helpful classes for those interviews, but you can also spend some time on Hackerrank/Leetcode and read CLRS for the theory behind it. So I'd say go for the first schedule and see if you can keep up, neither schedule will make a huge difference for recruiting.

Thanks! What classes would make me a competitive candidate for data science/analytics positions? My current plan is: 

Fall2019:
EECS 126
CS 170
DATA 100

Spring2020:
CS 189
EECS 127
HSS

Fall2020:
?
?
?

history.content: Hi I’m a transfer student going into my 3rd sem. I’ve taken all the 61 series and all the 16 series and 70 and I’ve gotten mostly A’s and a couple A-. I’m interested in ML/Data Science and in summer 2020 I’d like to do an internship in one of those fields. I’ll be taking 170 and 126 in the fall and I have a 8 hr course staff commitment. I’m either going to add data 100 or a hss. I was wondering how much would taking data 100 in the fall help me get interviews for DS related internships? My only fear is that although data 100 is a relatively low workload class taking it with 126 170 and course staff commitment would be too much. Any advice is appreciated !
history.subject: Classes for Data Science related position
